module.name: externally_conditioned_data_quality_criteria
module.name.french: Critères de qualité des données conditionnées en externe

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of quality criteria of product data of which acceptance conditions are defined in an external document.

inscope.li: the representation of a data quality criterion of which acceptance conditions are defined in an external document;
the representation of mechanism to refer the external document.

outscope.li: the format of an external document that specifies acceptance conditions.

definition.def: to state that all the partners of product data exchange or sharing reach the same understanding of the quality, its measurement and assessment of transferred or shared data

result of negotiations between the partners of product data exchange or sharing that ensures that all of them have the same understanding of the quality, its measurement and assessment of transferred or shared data
The agreement in this standard is formalized in an external document.

usage_guide.p: This Annex describes about the usage of this module.

ISO 10303-59 Edition-1 (PDQ-S) covers shape related data quality criteria with mathematically rigorous definitions. However, data which cause serious quality problems in real life product development processes is not limited to 3D shape data. We discussed this issue inviting industry experts from automotive industry, aerospace industry, die industry, electric parts industry and some others. They all agreed that;

ol.li: shape data quality is the core problem but it is not sufficient to resolve data quality problems in manufacturing area.
quality of some type of “non-shape CAD data” is also causing problems.
extension of target data to “non-shape CAD data” shall be challenged in the Edition-2 activity.

usage_guide.p: The above discussion shows that extension of target data to "non-shape CAD data" is effective for all manufacturers. The difference with shape data quality is that "non-shape CAD data" quality criteria are not truth-based or they have no mathematical background. Examples of such criteria are, CAD file name that does not satisfy business agreement, use of layer that does not satisfy business agreement, etc. To cope with these criteria, we have decided

ul.li: to shift these business-condition-oriented requirements to external document for which users are responsible to create, and
to develop a module which enables reference to those external documents.

usage_guide.p: This type of standard will considerably extend the usability of standards to real life user's data quality problems. We call hereafter this type of data quality as externally conditioned data quality.
1. These criteria are suited to be represented in an application module rather than a resource model

These criteria are not described based on clear technical base. Their measurement requirements and assessments do not have general applicability. Because of these characteristics, these criteria are difficult to be represented in a resource part. Instead, we have decided to develop a new application module for these criteria.

2. The module is developed as an extension of
module and
module.

Some externally conditioned data quality criteria are not related to shape. Even for criteria relating to shape, their contents are difficult to be specified clearly in technical viewpoints. For this reason, the module will be developed not as an extension of
module and
module, but as a specialization of
module and
module, namely, modules of general product data quality.
3. Measurement of the criterion had better refer to external documents.

Prior to each data exchange using externally conditioned data quality criteria, their contents concerning how to measure the quality and how to assess it are agreed among business partners. Since these agreements may change business by business, it is thought reasonable to treat these agreements as external documents outside of a standard for which users of the particular business are responsible to create.
usage_guide.b: F.3 How to use externally conditioned data quality criteria
usage_guide.p: Quality of product data is specified and used when a company declares data quality satisfied by a particular product data, when two or more companies agree on the level of data quality to be satisfied in exchanging/sharing product data among them or when representation of the result of evaluation of data quality of a specific product data is necessary. Requirements for the data quality can be specified using pdq modules.

If a requirement can be specified by a combination of criteria defined in
module, use those criteria. Refer to ISO 8000-311 for details of the usage of this module.
Otherwise, consider using criteria defined in Externally conditioned data quality criteria module. Use elements and mechanisms of the module as follows.
1. Selection of the criterion. First, select a criterion or criteria that fit to the agreed requirements from the subtypes of entity .
usage_guide.note: See F.4 for the classification of the criteria.
usage_guide.p: 2. Creation of the reference document
Create a document that clearly specifies how to measure and assess data quality for the selected criteria.

4. Assessment

Assessment is a logical one, because no numerical assessment where the measured quality is evaluated against a predefined threshold can be found for this type of criteria. However, if the agreed measurement requires numerical assessment, the assessment method must be clearly described in the referred external document.
5. Inspected element
The element of product data to be inspected is defined in a formal proposition of each subtype of the entity .
usage_guide.note: As identification of low quality element itself will be sufficient for externally conditioned data quality criterion, the representation of detailed portion where the problem occurs in the inspected element is not provided.

usage_guide.b: F.4 Classification of externally conditioned data quality criteria
usage_guide.p: Criteria in this module are classified into three categories.
1) Violation of agreed conditions on system environment
Exchange of product data fails if the system environment differs from the agreed one. This category includes criteria for detecting non-agreed accuracy parameter, scale and unit.
2) Use of restricted functionality

Companies that exchange/share product data may agree not to use a specific function or to restrict its usage when a trouble is expected caused by lack of a function or low capability in a particular CAD system is probable. This category includes criteria for detecting disallowed assembly relationship used, and excessive use of groups or layers..
3) Miscellaneous violation

This category covers other criteria for detecting miscellaneous violations against the agreement. It includes criteria for detecting the violation on naming or attribute values and criteria for detecting elements that are not referenced, not used or inconsistent.
